moves.1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nc3 Bb4: A trade off between aggression and defence.  The pin is broken but there is not any immediate pressure being placed against black's king side.
moves.5... d6 6. h3: Restricting Black's light square bishop and making the way clear for Nf3.
moves.6... Be6: Protecting the bishop's pawn and threatening an exchange which will double white pawns and thus weaken the King's pawn.
moves.7. a3 Ba5 8. b4 Bb6: This is a questionable maneuver, the black bishop has been driven to a more useful diagonal by a pawn charge which has no sustainable attack.
moves.9. Nf3 Nd4 10. O-O O-O 11. Bg5 c6: It would appear that black is preparing to launch an attack aimed as disrupting white’s central pawn structure
moves.12... Bxd4: Forces white to tie up either the queen or the bishop or lose material
moves.13. Qd2 d5 14. exd5 cxd5 15. Bb3 Qd7: Black now has a very strong king side attack whilst white’s queen is tied to the knight and cannot assist in the defence.
moves.16. Bxf6: White has given the only active piece on the king side and allowed black to half open the file in front of the white king.
moves.16... gxf6 17. Rae1:
?
In breaking the knight pin white has trapped his king’s rook
